text: Can you say a little bit more

about the future of South Africa
and the future of entrepreneurship?
Well I think South Africa is
at a very important phase.

We're doing everything
directionally right, fighting corruption.

We're just moving too slow 
on all of these things.
But the biggest -

the biggest issue for the country, 
I think, if you come here

and see it - it's a beautiful country
with magnificent people who,

no matter what they've been through, 
are tolerant and encouraging.

But the biggest issues are 
poverty and unemployment,
and how we overcome that.

And I think getting people to realize
entrepreneurship, getting rid of red

tape and government policy, being able
to give people access to capital markets,

venture capital in the early phase. 
In most markets, unlike the U.S,

there isn't a VC market where 
people can get access to capital.
It's difficult.

Bank debt is not the way you start
a business, you know.

So those are the kinds of things
that I think as a country

we've got to try and develop because it is
only entrepreneurship that can create
jobs at the scale we need.
So it I hope that Discovery is

an example of what you can achieve, 
breaking it down for people.
This is not beyond you.
It's possible.
You know, so critical.
I think the US has a culture -

I think if you're there,
you may not appreciate it -

of respect for 
entrepreneurship.
I think other countries don't.

They believe governments 
will provide, and they can't.
So we have to get a culture

of respecting business, of 
appreciating that it's a force for good.
Very, very important.
